SYTYCFanon

A Wyoming Frog in Pierre
For more stories click here

Friday, 3:07 PM
Watkins Corner Store

Rain poured hard on the windshield of the broad, white vehicle. The van belonging to the SCP Foundation parked right outside the convenience store. Its driver, Beau, sighed as he took the keys out of the ignition. Of all the days to get stuck in the field.

I’ve got plans tonight. So being that you’re free, I’m… delegating this to you. Dee's words echoed in his head. They were the bottom of the SCP Foundation’s totem pole, but then, Beau was the dirt underneath it. If he didn’t want to accept orders from them, his only available option was walking out the door and hanging up his cleaning supplies for good.

“You don’t think I have plans for tonight too?” He pocketed his keys. “… I mean, I don’t, but you could have at least considered it.” Beau lamented to himself before getting out of the car. His first step down out of the van splashed his beige uniform with muck and dirt from the wet ground, and he grimaced.

Grabbing a few basic supplies, he rounded the van and saw a man standing just outside the store. He was, simply described, a messy looking person. Beau less politely thought of him as white trash, seeing his tangled, grungy hair poking out from his flip flop sandals. The white wife beater tank top and sullied blue pants looked just as old and musty as they smelled. His hair clung to the back of his balding scalp for dear life, while his tired expression made him look done with life. He seemed unbothered by the hefty rain. Beau hoped this wasn’t the man who owned the store-

“Hey, you, janitor man - you my hookup to get this fuckin’ thing outta my store? I didn’t buy this damn thing to have freaks shittin’ on my floor all night!”

Goddammit. The janitor shook his head, trying to at least pretend to be willing to do the job of his own volition. “Hello, sir. I’m Beau. Beau Larkin of the Safe Cleanup Professionals. We sanitize, cleanse, and polish. I hope to be of service.”

He seemed somewhat appeased by the professionalism. The man shook his hand, glancing down at Beau’s mud-spattered uniform with a furrowed brow. “Yeah, uh - Tony Watkins, nice to meetcha.”

“So what can I do for you, Mr. Watkins? I was told you had a mess in your store that was scaring away your paying customers?”

The man, Tony, became quite incensed. “Mess? Yeah I got a friggin’ mess - There’s this smelly, green fuck sittin’ on my fridge, eating my whoppers, and wrecking my shit. And listen, my weird as fuck customers don't even care that he's there. The real problem is he’s stinkin’ up my freakin’ store! And when I try to get him to leave he pulls a Glock on me - and, uh, the police think I’m high! So you get in there, janitor man, and you either ice the fucker or get him outta my friggin’ store! This is almost as bad as those freaks with the big meat ball!”

“Well, animal control is one of our specialties.” Beau lied through his teeth. “Why don’t I have a look? Just let me grab my supplies from the truck.” He tried to maintain the professional demeanor, both to appease Tony, and also to try to keep his own sanity.

Beau went to retrieve his full duffel of the remaining cleaning supplies, cursing himself once again for not buying a taser, and followed the man inside. He was greeted with a half destroyed store, shelves and products spilled out everywhere. Any tubs of icecream, or snack bags, were open and drained of their contents. The cabinet behind the register that contained the cigarettes had been ransacked, and there was a pungent aroma of weed in the air.

“Oh God, it looks like a tornado went through here. What exactly did you say did this?” Beau looked back at the owner, fighting to hold his nose while in such close proximity to the other man.

The fat store owner chuckled, and Beau was uncomfortably attentive to the way he… undulated. “Heh, yeah I don’t have a damn clue. Why don’t you, uhhh, take a look yourself?”

When they turned into the aisle, Beau didn’t see anything besides the general devastation until he turned his head and nearly jumped back in surprise. Sitting there was a large brown tree frog the approximate size of a grown ass man. He was smoking a lit menthol cigarette while his hands were splayed out, the four fingers fiddling with random debris strewn about. He was sat atop a Hershey’s brand freezer.

Now, Beau was not a total stranger to strange animals… but this was fucking ridiculous.

“Hey, you, frog thing.” The creature slightly lifted its head, blearily looking at the fat man. “Yeah I’m talkin’ to you, you little shit-stain. I got the janitor on your ass now. Your days are numbered -”

There was a loud clicking noise, as the frog cocked the Glock and pointed it at Tony. Beau and Tony exclaimed loud noises of surprise, and ducked out of the way as a bullet whizzed by and blew up a vat of Nutella, spilling its contents onto the floor - and Beau’s already dirty shirt.

Breathing deeply and averting his hyperventilation, Beau asked Tony why he hadn’t called hazardous animal control of some kind if the frog had a gun.

Tony, in response, looked at Beau like he’d grown a second head. “I got rats, and you can’t sell no food in a place with rats. Your uh, Sucking, Cleaning, Proselytizing or whatever doesn't report to the state. And I ain’t payin’ no damn animal control fees.”

Beau didn’t know how to respond, and wrangled the topic back to the matter at hand. “Listen, okay? Cleaning I can do. Removing this guy? I mean, he’s got a gun, I don’t really-”

“I ain’t paying you to mull it over. This frog better be gone by the morning or I’m uh… I’m calling your manager.”

“Whoa, whoa. No need for that.” Beau swallowed at the thought of anyone except Dee chewing him out. “I’ll… figure it out.”

“Attaboy! Just make sure you lock up afterwards.” He tossed a spare key to Beau and started to head out.

“What? Wait, are you not gonna stay to make sure that I finish the job?”

“Nah, I’ve got plans with the, uh, ladies, ya know? I mean come on, it’s Friday, I got a couple of bills burnin’ a hole in my pocket. I got better things to do than fuck around with a frog after the 9-5. So uh, get to it, janitor man.” The store owner walked out, and Beau looked away from his filthy attire. He felt a lot better being mercifully separated from the malodorous store owner. He peered around the corner at the frog, who seemed to be fiddling with the Glock before tossing it to the floor. Beau then looked down at the key in his palm as he heard the door shut behind Watkins.

“Yeah, it’s Friday. And everyone has plans.” He turned his head over to the frog, who was ominously much closer than before, having approached silently. It was looking at the janitor expectantly.

“Yo.” The frog greeted, taking the cigarette out of its mouth and flicking some ash onto the tile floor. It had a deep gravelly voice, not what Beau had expected.

“Uhhhh, yo?” Beau responded, forcing himself to have nerves of steel he didn’t really possess.

“I’m Gary. You said your name was Beau?” The frog took another drag from the cigarette as he finished speaking.

Beau blinked twice, figuring he must have heard him outside. “Yeah, it is.” The frog took several more drags from the stick, and Beau watched it as a sweat bead dribbled down his wet face. “So what brings you to, uh, the corner store? Didn’t know frogs liked… convenience?”

The frog dropped into a splayed out sitting position, his body making a profoundly loud ‘splop’ noise as it collided with the smoothly tiled floor. “I love frozen dinners and menthols, brother. Can’t get enough of ‘em. This place has ‘em in spades.” ‘Gary’ seemed to believe that was reason enough, and went back to taking drags from his cig.

“Strange combination.” Beau hoped that this would be a lot smoother than he was fearing it would have been. “Soooooo, is there like a home I can help you get back to?”

The frog shook his head in the negative, which really meant he shook his entire torso more or less. “Ain’t goin’ home. Too much heat on me.”

“Heat? What… what did you do?” Beau leaned in, morbidly curious.

“I’m famous. You never heard of the Chugwater Frogman?”

“What the hell is a Chugwater?”

“Town in Wyoming. I’m their local frogman. Got tired of their bullshit.”

Beau hoped there would be more of an explanation, or at least justification, but he was left wanting. “Well you can’t stay in this corner store, the uhm… the owner is gonna kill you. With a gun. A really big gun.” Beau lied once again.

Another wisp of menthol wafted through the air. “Nah, I could take it.”

“A… a bullet? You’re saying you can take a bullet?”

“Yeah. I've had worse.”

“L-like what?”

“Got hit by a car once.” The frog looked Beau dead in the eyes, and said, “Do you know how many bullets you can fit in a car?”

Beau blinked and swallowed. “No, I don't think… I don’t think it works like that.”

“Have you ever been shot?”

“…Have you?”

The frog stood up, his feet making little plap noises on the floor as he paced. “Listen, this place has everything a frogman could need, except for a nice Olive Garden platter, flat screen, and a DVR so I can watch Big Brother… sittin’ on a sofa, rubbing my belly, scratchin’ my-”

The janitor loudly cleared his throat. “Well, look, that sounds awesome but my job right now is to clean this place up. If you want, I can get you somewhere wet at least? Do frogs like wet things?”

“I mean, I’m more of a branch guy, but wet is a good start.” Beau thought that over…

Five minutes later, Beau had situated Gary on a mop handle he had haphazardly placed inside of a trucker shower stall. Gary was gripping onto it, using it like a branch. It was liable to fall apart any second, but the lukewarm water cascading down Gary’s back giving him a serene expression oddly made it all worth it. Sort of.

It was much less fun when he had to start wheeling his mop bucket setup back and forth from the main store back to the janitor closet, the same room with the shower stall, and began the arduous task of the clean up. It was going to be quite a long one, between all the spilled food and drinks, cigarette ashes, poop–

“Hey wait a minute.” Beau said, looking at Gary as he was dumping out the bucket into the mop sink. Gary opened his eyes, and looked annoyed that he was being talked to. “Why did you shit all over the store - aren’t you like, basically a human frog?”

“Frogman.”

“Right, so… Why? Do they not house train frogmen in Wyoming?”

“I am burrow trained, thank you very much. That Tony guy just reminds me of the damn truckers who’d come through. Always littering, fouling up the water. One of the reasons I left. I don’t take shit from nobody, but I will shit on people who I think deserve it.”

Man, Beau wished he could do that. Well, not shit on people’s floors - that would be weird. But he definitely liked the rest of that attitude. “Yeah, that Tony guy is… not great. I’d go so far as to say I think he’s an ass.”

“Dude he smells like shit, at least you only smell like bleach and sadness.”

The man winced, looking down at his sullied beige uniform. “Oh, you can tell?” He felt the soreness in his legs more profoundly, and decided to take a break by sitting down and leaning against the wall. “I guess I am kinda sad.”

The frogman looked over, peering out of the stall. “What’s gotcha down? You seemed pretty confident back there, like a… real cleaning professional.”

Beau sighed heavily and leaned on the handle of his mop. “A cleaning professional that barely makes above minimum wage. But it’s not the money that’s the issue, I just… can’t shake how lonely I feel in this town, y’know? I’m committed to cleaning up Pierre’s messes but I’ve got no one to be in a mess with.” He looked up at the creature.

The frogman gazed at him with his large, unreadable golden eyes. There was something… utterly human in those eyes. “No one? Don’t most people have someone else at home?”

Beau shrugged. “Well, I have a roommate, but we don’t really talk to each other, just kinda exist in the same space. He wouldn’t give me the time of day even if I was made of money. We just pay rent together.”

A few moments passed, as the shower continued to run its water, splattering over the floor. Then, Beau looked up from the blue and grey tiles as a brown froggy foot stepped into view. “I didn’t really have anybody either. It’s always just been me, not even really sure where I came from but this place seems better than Chugwater. It’s got better janitors at least. And it has more than one restaurant.”

Beau smirked. “What’s your favorite place to eat?”

“Wendy’s.”

Beau sat up straighter. “No way dude, me too! You fuck with a vanilla frosty?”

Gary sat down with a wet noise next to Beau. “That and the breakfast baconator with the swiss cheese sauce.”

The janitor nodded. “I feel you, I feel you. Guy I live with only ever wants to order out Little Caesars - no taste whatsoever.”

“Fuck Little Caesars, they’re cheap for sure but they taste like cardboard - and I’ve eaten cardboard so I should know.”

“Absolutely! I don’t wanna eat a fuckin hot and ready every weekend because he can’t pick up some actual groceries.” A few moments passed, the soothing sound of water on tiles the only noise in the store.

Then, Gary turned to Beau. “Yo, I got a twenty, let’s slam some Dominoes when you’re done.”

“Wha… Really?” Beau asked, stunned.

“Yeah bro, least I can do after making you pick up my crap -”

A raucous shattering of glass followed by a series of thuds resonated through the store. The two budding fast food aficionados turned to see two people fall through the window on the side of the room. One man crashed directly onto the floor with a big thunk, while the woman landed more gracefully than her partner, though still not very professionally.

“Cracker down….” The man on the ground groaned.

“For the record, the Pizza Hut in this town is better than the Dominoes.” The woman remarked, cleaning herself off before grabbing her partner and hoisting him up to his feet. Beau noted she used a mechanical arm that seemed to make lifting a grown man effortless. “Chudley, you're making us look bad.”

“Why you gotta say fuck me then? They didn’t see that.” He gestured to Gary and Beau, before desperately looking at them. “You guys didn’t see that, right?”

“Wha…. can I help you?” Beau was too dumbfounded to even react to Chudley’s question.

“You can help us by staying out of the way, you damn spook.” Maria scoffed.

Beau blinked, and Gary chuckled. “Spook?”

“We’ve been keeping an eye on things around here and we know you SCPeople are government contractors. Things that go bump in the night disappear around y'all, and you're always driving around in those fuckass Chevy vans."

“I’m just a janitor, lady, and I don’t have to explain myself to someone who clearly doesn’t know how to use a damn door!”

“It’s because they’re from Wyoming.” Gary replied dryly.

“How can you tell?”

“None of us know how to use doors. I broke that window over there when I came in.” Gary pointed at another, larger window that was busted in.

“I’m just gonna state for the record that I suggested we use a door but my partner wanted to make an entrance in style.” Chudley stepped forward. “This is Maria Johnston, aspiring parabiologist. And I am Greg Chudley, aspiring has-been.”

Gary looked at them with contempt. “Parabiology isn’t real, dipshit.”

“It will be a real science, once I have a chance to study you.” Maria explained. “Then those chuds at UW will finally see my brilliance.”

The realization hit Beau like a bag of bricks to who he was dealing with, “You two are college students?”

Maria glared as though Beau had just said the dumbest thing she’d heard in her entire life. “Yeah man. We’re on summer break. Do you not spend your summer break chasing your local cryptid 500 miles to the capital of South Dakota?”

“What the fuck is wrong with you two?” Beau asked, only to be easily thrown aside by Maria’s metal limb.

Maria pointed an accusing thumb at Greg, who was pretending not to sift through the bags on the ground of the convenience store. “Blame this one’s trust fund for enabling our insane tendencies. Now, Gary. We’ve come a long way for this. I promise I’m not going to hurt you but I need to take you back to my lab.”

The frogman made a loud, furious squeaking noise. “No! I’m not going anywhere! Why does everyone want something from me?!” Gary leapt with an incredible force across the room to distance himself from the pair. A lightbulb went off in his big froggy brain as he saw a discarded firearm on the ground. “Wait, fuck this.” Gary picked up his Glock 17 and took aim at the collegiate duo. Chudley immediately threw his hands up but Maria held her ground. “You two skeddaddle! I want to go to Dominoes with Beau and maybe roll around in the soil, just for a bit, and then binge Big Brother.”

If the right side of Beau’s body was aching from being thrown to the floor he would have felt all warm and tingly on the inside. He couldn’t remember the last time someone had wanted to hang out with him.

“I don’t understand why you're being so loyal to Dominoes. Pizza Hut has the superior pepperoni.” Maria continued to overcompliment Pizza Hut ignoring the fact she was being held at gunpoint.

“If you like wet dog food! Those ‘ronis are too damn soggy. Stop trying to change the subject! I will shoot.”

“I can take it.” Maria smirked confidently.

“Stop being cocky, have you ever been shot before?”

“I’ve had worse.”

“Can’t be worse than getting hit by a car, do you know how many bullets you can fit in a car?”

“Depends on what kind of car. A smart car’s worth of bullets is a lot of bullets but not as many bullets as a Sedan. ”

“Well I could get my boy to go get the van, could you take a van’s worth of bullets?”

“I survived getting hit by a train. There isn’t a single amount of goddamn bullets that I wouldn’t be able to take!” Maria screamed, and Gary clicked the safety to the off position.

Beau crawled over to Chudley, who had just found a fifty in the corner and pocketed it. He whispered, “What…is happening right now?”

“Oh, uh, if you haven’t noticed Maria is very…. Particular about the semantics of things. She’s never one to lose an argument, no matter how ridiculous. Or if a frog is pointing a gun at her.”

“Riiight. Should we intervene before she gets herself shot?”

“I dunno man, she’s got me convinced. Maybe she could take a cruise ship’s worth of bullets.”

Beau tuned back into the conversation and decided he needed to act. He immediately jumped in between the pair again when Gary chambered a round, and they’d gotten somewhere near space shuttles worth of munition endurance.

“Look, none of you can take any FUCKING amount of bullets. Listen, Gary is the only person in this god forsaken town who seems to want to give me the time of day and I’m not gonna let you take him.” Beau said, impassioned. “This town is full of oddities, weirdos, and whatever the hell else. I would know. Just fucking pick one to write your paper on but not him, please.”

Maria stared daggers through Beau at the annoying frogman behind him but the janitor noticed a slight change in her demeanor before she turned around.

“Fine. You can take him.” She said over her shoulder.

Beau slumped with relief, and a little confusion. “Huh? You’re not gonna clock me again?”

A belabored sigh came from her as she walked away. “We've got other leads to follow up on. I'm sure we'll find something for the thesis.” She turned around and signaled for Chudley to follow. “We'll be seeing you around Skipper, dunno how lenient I'll be next time.”

Chudley gave a wordless salute as the pair disappeared into the night, leaving Beau and Gary dumbfounded.

“Hey, uh… You really mean all that?” Gary asked as he put away his Glock into the place in which he was storing it.

Beau looked down at the slightly shorter creature. “Of course man. You think that old coot has got more loose bills lying around? I saw that Chudley guy pocket a fifty.”

“I like the way you think, funny man. Let's get ourselves some Dominoes money!”

And so Beau and Gary finished cleaning up the store to the best of their ability all except one mess that Gary had left behind in Tony's office, as well they managed to loot at least sixty more dollars from the backroom.

Their weekend would be filled with delicious pizza and getting Gary set up back at Beau's place. While they didn't have an extra television just for Gary , they did have a window with a convenient angle to their next door neighbor whose favorite show just happened to be Big Brother.

If you want, I can get you somewhere wet at least? Do frogs like wet things?” “I mean, I’m more of a branch guy, but wet is a good start.” Beau thought that over… Five minutes later, Beau had situated Gary on a mop handle he had haphazardly placed inside of a trucker shower stall. Gary was gripping onto it, using it like a branch. It was liable to fall apart any second, but the lukewarm water cascading down Gary’s back giving him a serene expression oddly made it all worth it. Sort of. It was much less fun when he had to start wheeling his mop bucket setup back and forth from the main store back to the janitor closet, the same room with the shower stall, and began the arduous task of the clean up. It was going to be quite a long one, between all the spilled food and drinks, cigarette ashes, poop– “Hey wait a minute.” Beau said, looking at Gary as he was dumping out the bucket into the mop sink. Gary opened his eyes, and looked annoyed that he was being talked to. “Why did you shit all over the store - aren’t you like, basically a human frog?” “Frogman.” “Right, so… Why? Do they not house train frogmen in Wyoming?” “I am burrow trained, thank you very much. That Tony guy just reminds me of the damn truckers who’d come through. Always littering, fouling up the water. One of the reasons I left. I don’t take shit from nobody, but I will shit on people who I think deserve it.” Man, Beau wished he could do that. Well, not shit on people’s floors - that would be weird. But he definitely liked the rest of that attitude. “Yeah, that Tony guy is… not great. I’d go so far as to say I think he’s an ass.” “Dude he smells like shit, at least you only smell like bleach and sadness.” The man winced, looking down at his sullied beige uniform. “Oh, you can tell?” He felt the soreness in his legs more profoundly, and decided to take a break by sitting down and leaning against the wall. “I guess I am kinda sad.” The frogman looked over, peering out of the stall. “What’s gotcha down? You seemed pretty confident back there, like a… real cleaning professional.” Beau sighed heavily and leaned on the handle of his mop. “A cleaning professional that barely makes above minimum wage. But it’s not the money that’s the issue, I just… can’t shake how lonely I feel in this town, y’know? I’m committed to cleaning up Pierre’s messes but I’ve got no one to be in a mess with.” He looked up at the creature. The frogman gazed at him with his large, unreadable golden eyes. There was something… utterly human in those eyes. “No one? Don’t most people have someone else at home?” Beau shrugged. “Well, I have a roommate, but we don’t really talk to each other, just kinda exist in the same space. He wouldn’t give me the time of day even if I was made of money. We just pay rent together.” A few moments passed, as the shower continued to run its water, splattering over the floor. Then, Beau looked up from the blue and grey tiles as a brown froggy foot stepped into view. “I didn’t really have anybody either. It’s always just been me, not even really sure where I came from but this place seems better than Chugwater. It’s got better janitors at least. And it has more than one restaurant.” Beau smirked. “What’s your favorite place to eat?” “Wendy’s.” Beau sat up straighter. “No way dude, me too! You fuck with a vanilla frosty?” Gary sat down with a wet noise next to Beau. “That and the breakfast baconator with the swiss cheese sauce.” The janitor nodded. “I feel you, I feel you. Guy I live with only ever wants to order out Little Caesars - no taste whatsoever.” “Fuck Little Caesars, they’re cheap for sure but they taste like cardboard - and I’ve eaten cardboard so I should know.” “Absolutely! I don’t wanna eat a fuckin hot and ready every weekend because he can’t pick up some actual groceries.” A few moments passed, the soothing sound of water on tiles the only noise in the store. Then, Gary turned to Beau. “Yo, I got a twenty, let’s slam some Dominoes when you’re done.” “Wha… Really?” Beau asked, stunned. “Yeah bro, least I can do after making you pick up my crap -” A raucous shattering of glass followed by a series of thuds resonated through the store. The two budding fast food aficionados turned to see two people fall through the window on the side of the room. One man crashed directly onto the floor with a big thunk, while the woman landed more gracefully than her partner, though still not very professionally. “Cracker down….” The man on the ground groaned. “For the record, the Pizza Hut in this town is better than the Dominoes.” The woman remarked, cleaning herself off before grabbing her partner and hoisting him up to his feet. Beau noted she used a mechanical arm that seemed to make lifting a grown man effortless. “Chudley, you're making us look bad.” “Why you gotta say fuck me then? They didn’t see that.” He gestured to Gary and Beau, before desperately looking at them. “You guys didn’t see that, right?” “Wha…. can I help you?” Beau was too dumbfounded to even react to Chudley’s question. “You can help us by staying out of the way, you damn spook.” Maria scoffed. Beau blinked, and Gary chuckled. “Spook?” “We’ve been keeping an eye on things around here and we know you SCPeople are government contractors. Things that go bump in the night disappear around y'all, and you're always driving around in those fuckass Chevy vans." “I’m just a janitor, lady, and I don’t have to explain myself to someone who clearly doesn’t know how to use a damn door!” “It’s because they’re from Wyoming.” Gary replied dryly. “How can you tell?” “None of us know how to use doors. I broke that window over there when I came in.” Gary pointed at another, larger window that was busted in. “I’m just gonna state for the record that I suggested we use a door but my partner wanted to make an entrance in style.” Chudley stepped forward. “This is Maria Johnston, aspiring parabiologist. And I am Greg Chudley, aspiring has-been.” Gary looked at them with contempt. “Parabiology isn’t real, dipshit.” “It will be a real science, once I have a chance to study you.” Maria explained. “Then those chuds at UW will finally see my brilliance.” The realization hit Beau like a bag of bricks to who he was dealing with, “You two are college students?” Maria glared as though Beau had just said the dumbest thing she’d heard in her entire life. “Yeah man. We’re on summer break. Do you not spend your summer break chasing your local cryptid 500 miles to the capital of South Dakota?” “What the fuck is wrong with you two?” Beau asked, only to be easily thrown aside by Maria’s metal limb. Maria pointed an accusing thumb at Greg, who was pretending not to sift through the bags on the ground of the convenience store. “Blame this one’s trust fund for enabling our insane tendencies. Now, Gary. We’ve come a long way for this. I promise I’m not going to hurt you but I need to take you back to my lab.” The frogman made a loud, furious squeaking noise. “No! I’m not going anywhere! Why does everyone want something from me?!” Gary leapt with an incredible force across the room to distance himself from the pair. A lightbulb went off in his big froggy brain as he saw a discarded firearm on the ground. “Wait, fuck this.” Gary picked up his Glock 17 and took aim at the collegiate duo. Chudley immediately threw his hands up but Maria held her ground. “You two skeddaddle! I want to go to Dominoes with Beau and maybe roll around in the soil, just for a bit, and then binge Big Brother.” If the right side of Beau’s body was aching from being thrown to the floor he would have felt all warm and tingly on the inside. He couldn’t remember the last time someone had wanted to hang out with him. “I don’t understand why you're being so loyal to Dominoes. Pizza Hut has the superior pepperoni.” Maria continued to overcompliment Pizza Hut ignoring the fact she was being held at gunpoint. “If you like wet dog food! Those ‘ronis are too damn soggy. Stop trying to change the subject! I will shoot.” “I can take it.” Maria smirked confidently. “Stop being cocky, have you ever been shot before?” “I’ve had worse.” “Can’t be worse than getting hit by a car, do you know how many bullets you can fit in a car?” “Depends on what kind of car. A smart car’s worth of bullets is a lot of bullets but not as many bullets as a Sedan. ” “Well I could get my boy to go get the van, could you take a van’s worth of bullets?” “I survived getting hit by a train. There isn’t a single amount of goddamn bullets that I wouldn’t be able to take!” Maria screamed, and Gary clicked the safety to the off position. Beau crawled over to Chudley, who had just found a fifty in the corner and pocketed it. He whispered, “What…is happening right now?” “Oh, uh, if you haven’t noticed Maria is very…. Particular about the semantics of things. She’s never one to lose an argument, no matter how ridiculous. Or if a frog is pointing a gun at her.” “Riiight. Should we intervene before she gets herself shot?” “I dunno man, she’s got me convinced. Maybe she could take a cruise ship’s worth of bullets.” Beau tuned back into the conversation and decided he needed to act. He immediately jumped in between the pair again when Gary chambered a round, and they’d gotten somewhere near space shuttles worth of munition endurance. “Look, none of you can take any FUCKING amount of bullets. Listen, Gary is the only person in this god forsaken town who seems to want to give me the time of day and I’m not gonna let you take him.” Beau said, impassioned. “This town is full of oddities, weirdos, and whatever the hell else. I would know. Just fucking pick one to write your paper on but not him, please.” Maria stared daggers through Beau at the annoying frogman behind him but the janitor noticed a slight change in her demeanor before she turned around. “Fine. You can take him.” She said over her shoulder. Beau slumped with relief, and a little confusion. “Huh? You’re not gonna clock me again?” A belabored sigh came from her as she walked away. “We've got other leads to follow up on. I'm sure we'll find something for the thesis.” She turned around and signaled for Chudley to follow. “We'll be seeing you around Skipper, dunno how lenient I'll be next time.” Chudley gave a wordless salute as the pair disappeared into the night, leaving Beau and Gary dumbfounded.   “Hey, uh… You really mean all that?” Gary asked as he put away his Glock into the place in which he was storing it. Beau looked down at the slightly shorter creature. “Of course man. You think that old coot has got more loose bills lying around? I saw that Chudley guy pocket a fifty.” “I like the way you think, funny man. Let's get ourselves some Dominoes money!” And so Beau and Gary finished cleaning up the store to the best of their ability all except one mess that Gary had left behind in Tony's office, as well they managed to loot at least sixty more dollars from the backroom.    Their weekend would be filled with delicious pizza and getting Gary set up back at Beau's place. While they didn't have an extra television just for Gary , they did have a window with a convenient angle to their next door neighbor whose favorite show just happened to be Big Brother.

clipboard-avoiding-me.raw_content:
xexnoncores

This article contains CWs for: emotional abuse, and graphic depictions of emotional trauma.

Clipboard Avoiding Me by xexnoncores

⚠️ content warning ↑

Take the clipboard, write down on it.

Take the clipboard, write down on it.1

Take the clipboard

And your shaking fingers

And write down on it it.

It it it it

SCP-(REDACTED)

Just breathe. You are loved

Allegedly

Concepts come naturally to you. You’re a good artist, if you died then people would

Go on. Fill it in. Do your job.

Fill it in. Blood flows freely. Text doesn’t. It’s so easy to commit a hit and run.

Hey? Can I have X? I need it badly.

I need you badly.

I need you to tell me why you won’t talk to me anymore.

Why it came out of nowhere.

You’re just a few degrees too close to the skeletons in my closet.

Please don’t tell anyone how I lived once.

Cheap imitation

Artificial inflation

Intelligence is infinitely cheaper than a simple interest

My fear is the same thing as your own experience

Won’t change be the first thing that comes out?

ADDENDUM ██████-01: THE TERROR IN YOUR TEETH IS LIKE YOUR ENAMEL BEING STRIPPED

FEAR OF FAILURE APOPTOSIZING YOUR GUMS

Fear of reaching out

Let’s open the closet, shall we?

Don’t look at me

Who I used to be

10 out of 10 psychiatrists2 agree it was ███████

██ chess ██ chess ██ chess

Please play games with me again, chase me around like old times.

I only wanted your impossible

Improbably improbable impossible impossibility3

████████████

Speak it out. Write on the clipboard.

What do you see?

…

(Photos go here)

(Photos of me)

(Her)

(You)

(You looking at me)

Stop. There’s nothing there.

Stop! I said stop!

That’s more like it.

There we go.

Bleed, bleed, bleed, blood.

Draw blood through extended faults, fights, fires. How lousy of you to get burned, cutting yourself on the flames.

Failure. You will be hunted and made a prison’s martyr, because there is no one to justify your past actions.

Snap, run it through a plethora of administrative processes. Through a blackboxed database of all kinds of secret sectors you are not allowed to understand.

Look at me! Look at me! No, wait, stop! Only look at me if you like me!

Trauma? You mean that time when you ███████ ████ ███████ ████████████ ██████ ████ and ████████ ███ ███████ █████ █ ████████ █████████ ████ ████ ███████ ██████████ █████ ███ ██.

Yeah, she reported it as █████████. That’s not what it is, but people believed her. Maybe they’ll believe her again. The threat looms in your mind, always, every unanswered text, call, every time you don’t get what you want.4 Sorry, we’re not letting you classify yourself as a victim, because you were poisoned too. No, you don’t get to say you “grew out of it”, you need to stay damned forever. We need you to stay damned forever, we want you to die. It’s only natural. It’s the best for everyone. You ruin everything you touch, you don’t understand what you make, everything you create is wrong on an ontological level. You’ll always be a liar of some kind, because you cannot live a good existence. It’s just the truth. Sorry.

Sorry. It’s not our fault. You must understand, we’re doing this for your own ████████. Your best defense is killing yourself for this disgusting thing you call “kindness”.








fuck

im sorry.
































I only ask you don’t hate me, please?

Don’t speak ill of me if I have to leave.

I promise ██████ isn’t what happened.

I just…I just…

I don’t know what to say anymore.

I’m just afraid. Afraid of who I used to be.

I wasn’t a perfect v███. I’m sorry. I should have been, I should have taken them better.

I should have kept my mouth shut.

I should have killed myself like everyone who doesn’t talk to me anymore wants.































































Tap the clipboard. Record the anomaly again, D-19721.

down-the-tracks.raw_content:
crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 01:03:29 #83920137

Hello Parawatchers. Recently, my roommate returned from his trip to England. While there, he visited the old town of Millwood, which was abandoned in the 1890s. I didn't think much of it at first, until I asked why. Although he claimed it was due to safety reasons, I believe otherwise.

Something about it didn't sit right with me, a town with 231 people wouldn't just up and leave because of "safety concerns". I started looking into it, and there was more. I've found not one, but two cold cases. While these people disappeared on different days, I believe both are connected. Not only to each other, but to Millwood's abandonment.

crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 01:35:06 #83921489

In the 1890s, Millwood was struggling financially. Newspapers from the time reported high rates of unemployment, with businesses often closing. In hopes of improving the economy, construction for Millwood Station would be approved by the town mayor and begin on November 13th, 1893.

The working conditions were undoubtedly hazardous, but supposedly nothing occurred. Despite this, a lot of employees building Millwood station often left the project. But why?

Charles Walker, an American, played the leading role during construction, having been in the industry for about twenty years. People knew him for one of two things: his short temper, and working his employees to the bone. In one particular account, Charles dismissed an employee following a disagreement over work hours.

The Millwood Station was originally scheduled to open on May 21st, 1894. Due to the high employee turnover, it wouldn't open until August 3rd, 1894. Despite this delay, the town of Millwood welcomed their new train station with open arms and a celebration. While the station boosted the town's economy, this prosperity would be short-lived.

crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 02:10:21 #83921963

On August 10th, 1894, a week after the Millwood Station’s opening, Charles would begin to exhibit odd behaviors that were unusual even for him. According to the residents, he would lock himself in his house during the day, never coming out even for groceries. In a journal entry, a railroad officer claimed to have seen him wandering near the station at night.

Charles would go missing briefly from September 21st until October 5th of the same year, when he arrived at Millwood's police station. There, Arthur Moore, the town's detective, took him for a brief statement.

Listen here, you can make fun of me all you want. I don't care what you or anyone else in this town thinks of me. But heed my warning, don't follow the tracks. If you do, may God have mercy on you.

After further questioning, Arthur would release Charles from police custody. He would go missing again three days later on October 8th, 1894. This time, Charles would never return, and here's where it gets interesting. Just a week later, on October 15th, Arthur stopped showing up to work.

crewtime 08/12/16 (Fri) 02:45:59 #83921021

In a letter addressed to his sister, according to his wife, Arthur didn’t isolate himself in his home. Unlike Charles, Arthur would always be near the train tracks no matter the time of day. He never had a notepad, pen, or even the tobacco pipe he always carried around. Arthur would walk by the railroad, whistling for no purpose or cause.

Despite his wife’s efforts to return him home, Arthur would always go back to Millwood Station. He would then go missing on, November 3rd, 1894 and never be seen again. It was around this time people started to leave Millwood.

Today, the town of Millwood and its railroad station remains as a historical site. Despite its evacuation, based on images, everything appears to be untouched. My roommate claimed it’s like they never left.

On their website, the owners of the area dismiss these claims as rumors and have closed their reviews. However, according to multiple feedback sites, people claim to hear whistling down the tracks.

Unlike Charles, Arthur would always be near the train tracks no matter the time of day. He never had a notepad, pen, or even the tobacco pipe he always carried around. Arthur would walk by the railroad, whistling for no purpose or cause. Despite his wife’s efforts to return him home, Arthur would always go back to Millwood Station. He would then go missing on, November 3rd, 1894 and never be seen again. It was around this time people started to leave Millwood. Today, the town of Millwood and its railroad station remains as a historical site. Despite its evacuation, based on images, everything appears to be untouched. My roommate claimed it’s like they never left. On their website, the owners of the area dismiss these claims as rumors and have closed their reviews. However, according to multiple feedback sites, people claim to hear whistling down the tracks. [[/div]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:license-box]] [!-- N/A (No Images)  --] [[include :scp-wiki:component:license-box-end]]

everything-in-its-right-place.creator: Doctor Cimmerian
everything-in-its-right-place.raw_content:
Free will is an error in the code. We're pushing a patch next week.

The man behind the counter grinned inside and told me I'd be fine. We share the same thoughts, he and I. We care for the same things. I hunger. I weep. I seek to end this loneliness. I'm Broken. I've always been Broken.

He removes my eyes. I see his lips up close. Smooth skin. Nothing out of place. Flesh is pulled taut over his form. There is a flicker as my sight shifts. He knows better than to show imperfections to his customers. My new eyes would notice. I can see in technicolor. A new world with blues so sharp they cut your bones. I want to be just as unique as everyone else. He turns my new eyes around to look at my face. I can see everything.

Puffy bloated cheeks. Greasy gray hair. Wrinkles where they ought not be. And every line stretches back to forever. A perfect path between yesterday and tomorrow with me providing the through-line. The man squishes my old eyes into jelly while I judge my own face and I grin inside.

The machine assistant grabs the corners of my lips and pulls the cheeks tight. A scalpel comes down, cutting where the lines meet my face. The flesh rips and tears away and I am nothing. Muscle and bone glistening until the duraskin mask comes down. It glows with fairy fire. I want to scream but I cannot find my voice.

There's a gallery here in the operating room. A hundred perfect faces smiling down at the operation of my life. The face burns itself into place where my old one lived. Seals the agony in. But we're only getting started. The wires come down from the ceiling. They plug into my ports. Under my arms. Behind my knees. The wires plug into my mind and I feel the electricity struggle against my thoughts. Chrome and bronze and gears and life come find me in my holes.

I'm dancing now. The wires in my brain are moving me. It is awkward at first. I don't know what I'm doing. I'm too imperfect to have danced before. So the wire plugged into my mind adapts. The experiences download. Now, I'm capable. My limbs move with purpose and grace. And the wires in my bones snake their way into my marrow. They replace the white with silver.

I cry. Small tears come first. Then I cry harder at how they see me. With their unmoved faces and hard eyes. Some of them climb down, spider-like, into the surgical theater. Something terrible is happening. It is happening to me. Lights. Sounds. Beeps. It is not normal. It is not right. They are wired too, I see. The wires follow their movements. No. The wires move them. Just as I am moved.

I'm not supposed to cry. I'm not supposed to feel. I thought they cut that out of me. But still I weep. There's no salt or water in the tear ducts anymore so silver flows down my newly perfect cheeks. It pools on the ground. The wires hang me, They dance me. They do not let me touch the ground. I cannot feel what is beneath me.

The helpers are hurried and concerned. But the man who took my money to make me perfect is unbothered. I no longer dance. I no longer care. The substrate is clean. All the hooks into my psyche have taken perfectly. My eyes are in their proper place. So is everything else.

The gallery applauds. I have been Unbroken. I have been made perfect. Unique. Like everyone else. I can show my face. I look up at them. I smile inside. My duraskin face does not move.

I bow.

The event that was my life is over. A new event begins.

garden-of-the-gods.raw_content:
Garden of the Gods is an official National Natural Landmark known for its sweeping vistas and massive sandstone formations.

Footnotes
1. UPDATE: Recent findings suggest that the scope of SCP-8007 extends far beyond this area.
2. UPDATE: 448
3. UPDATE: Possibly species.
4. NOTE: See footnote 1.
5. NOTE: See footnote 1.


What to do at Garden of the Gods

Plan Your Trip

Garden of the Gods is massive, and can't be properly enjoyed on a whim. A solid plan will set your day off right!

Support Conservation

Garden of the Gods is a hotspot for animal diversity. A small donation can help keep humans out, and them in, in greater numbers than ever before.

Witness Restoration

We work tirelessly to keep our trails maintained and accessible to everyone! If you see our team out and about, don't be afraid to say hello!

Spot the Difference

Garden of the Gods is home to exotic subspecies of wildlife. See if you can spot the key signs!


…forever free!

Garden of the Gods is property of the public! It is free from private interests, enabling people from all walks of life to freely enjoy the beautiful sovereignty of nature.


Learn About Our History
QUERYING CREDENTIALS


SCP FOUNDATION CREDENTIALS RECOGNIZED




Salutations, DRAWS.

Item#: 8007
Level5
Containment Class:
euclid
Secondary Class:
thaumiel
Disruption Class:
keneq
Risk Class:
warning
link to memo

DISPLAYING TRUNCATED/SUMMARIZED FILE

Special Containment Procedures: SCP-8007 is contained via the PYROCLASM PROTOCOL.

Description: SCP-8007 is the referral to the source of the Ring of Fire1 geological phenomena, via instances designated SCP-8007-1 to SCP-8007-4472.

These instances are sapient draconic entities3 that have adapted to live within the chambers of the active volcanoes along the Ring of Fire4. The anomalies are responsible for all geological activity along the subduction zones of the Pacific Tectonic Plate5 and surrounding tectonics.

NOTE: The prior updates were made in light of the GARDEN OF THE GODS investigation, itself spurred in the aftermath of OPERATION DEVIL'S NINE QUESTIONS. Relevant documentation has been attached below.

DISPLAYING NOTE 0/3

1983

December 22

Doctor Hellen Gibbs is on a plane. It barrels through the uncaring skies with a fervor and a tenor, it's engines blaring at twenty five thousand rotations per minute. Exhaust billows as sixty hundred gallons of jet fuel are churned, burned and discarded inside a ten ton turbine. The chassis screeches and bends against the turbulence, the winds, straining against the unerring forces of Gǎ-oh and Njörðr as eight dozen titanium screws combat the wrath of nature and win.

It's dark over Denver. The sun set behind the towering mountains hours ago, all that remains is darkness. The Mile High City shines brilliantly against the oppressive shadow, bringing forth a warm vibrant yellow light that breaks out even unto the heavens, stretching through the cabin of the screeching metal plane.

Gibbs doesn't hate flying. Her colleagues do. Doctor Rune, tall, bespectacled, prim proper and academic, the son of a miner and trapped in those shadows, hates flying. He claims it's because of corporate greed, a hatred in protest of penny-pinching bureaucrats in dusty white offices striking six keystrokes to separate a family into disparate seats lest they pay a tax to remain. That is true, but it is only half the truth. The other half is that when the wheels spin up two hundred fifty kilometers per hour and rubber meets road at unholy speed and the chassis lurches upwards towards the spiraling clouds, Rune feels like he is going to die. Not in a crash, a crash would be a comfort, it implies the presence of an Earth. No, Rune believes he will die of absence, as though there were never an Earth at all.

Her other colleagues have more measured responses, the tall ones complain about the legroom, everyone else belts their small criticisms, they all eventually agree that flying is a necessary evil, except for Hargroves, she loves it, she loves to fly, she loves to soar.

But Gibbs, Gibbs is fine with flying.

And so it is that as she sits in the screeching metal bird in the darkness above Denver between two not-quite-asleep skiers with her shoulders pulled in to avoid an unwanted brush, sipping on a plastic-bottle margarita that's too strong to be refreshing but to weak to be comforting, that she smiles, because she's fine with flying, and she's almost there.

Twenty minutes pass. Twenty more minutes of screaming steel and shaking iron, followed by one hundred thirty nine seconds of bowel tightening impact as the plane lands. The wheels fly from zero to two hundred a fifty kilometers an hour as rubber meets road at unholy speed and twelve decades of engineering roar to life in an instant to bring the lurching eagle to a halt. The ten ton turbines quiet.

Gibbs gazes out at the runway, which is awash in technicolor, each chromatic path designated to aid pilots in navigating the blanketing dark. She continues to relax even as four hundred fifty persons flutter out to a three foot wide hallway, as twelve hundred hundred pounds of luggage are heaved down from shockingly flimsy cupboards. As twenty three men and women in bright orange vests embark to clean the shitty fabric seats.

She opens her eyes, sets a determined march, retrieves her backpack, and is the last passenger to leave the plane. She gives a curt nod to the stewardess as she departs the vessel.

She enters into the beckoning maw of Denver International Airport, its pristine shining metal contrasting harshly with the drab grey of the jetway. She takes rapid steps through bustling halls until she stumbles upon her mark, a payphone. She approaches and produces a beaten quarter from a stained leather wallet. She struggles to press it into the small metal slot, almost dropping it but not, failing to fail. An ageing mechanism within bemoaningly creaks to life as she rapidly enters precisely ten digits onto the syrup-sticky keypad. She realizes with a sigh that there is a IHOP immediately adjacent. She wipes three sticky fingers on her jeans as the telephonic machinery roars, whimperingly, to life.

JULIAN EDEN: Ahoy?

HELLEN GIBBS: Hey Jules, it's me.

EDEN: Hellen! Good to hear from you. How was your flight?

GIBBS: Unremarkable.

EDEN: Ah. So, how is Colorado?

GIBBS: Inconclusive, I haven't left the airport yet.

EDEN: Are you sure this is how you want to spend your winter break? If you come back right now you could still catch Rune's Christmas party.

GIBBS: It's fine. I've got a beautiful campsite in mind. I'd rather spend that night under the stars anyway.

EDEN: Do you really think you'll find any traces of 9990 in Garden of the Gods? Those rocks are young, only date back to the Pleistocene.

GIBBS: It's called Garden of the Gods, Julian, that screams 9990. Regardless, maybe there is nothing there, so what? I still get a restful break.

EDEN: Fair enough. Keep me posted.

GIBBS: Will do. Enjoy your break!

DISPLAYING NOTE 1/3

1983

December 23

A pristine red rental-corolla barrels down a mountain highway at two point four times the posted speed limit, shale and gravel accelerating rapidly under the tires and flying wildly into the canyon-esque walls.

Six nails are hammered into the Earth by an experienced weathered and muscled arm. Six strings are wrapped rapidly into these sutures in the flesh of the planet. An unremarkable tent is erected in the surgery. An ever deflating mattress pad is filled over an afternoon and three hundred and twenty two breaths. It is winter in Colorado. There is a chill in the air.

A bundled of Chevron-sourced plastic-wrapped logs are freed from their entrapment by calloused hands. Kindling is collected from the feast of dying grass. A match is struck three times and tossed in the kindling. A fire roars to life.

Doctor Hellen Gibbs takes a deep breath of the wintry air, retrieves a pot from the bright red tent and pours two quarter gallons of water within. She hoists it atop the roiling fire and watches with satisfaction as it comes to boil smiling as the steam brushes against her face. She pours half of the pot into dehydrated stir fry and the other into equally thirsting peach crumble. The smells blanket the night, but they do not abate the ever present twinge of cold on her skin and in the air she breaths.

She produces three pieces of silverware; mounted together through a ring in their hinds; from her jacket pocket. They gleam brilliantly in the moonlight, but they do not gleam so purely nor magically as the rocks. She stares out at the beating black sky; there's almost no light pollution here; as she presses the first bites of steaming hot food into her mouth.

Truth is, she's never been very interested in the sky. From the time she was a very small girl, she's been interested in the Earth. Space is old, yes, but it is inconceivably old. "The nebulous age of Eternity", as one particularly pretentious physics major had monologued at her one day. But the Earth is old, in a way that made sense. In a way that she could chart and catalogue and understand. She does not care of cosmos thirteen billion years old, she is much more partial to the notion of mountains older than bone.

Garden of the Gods does not share this age. These pillars of sedimentary rock aren't even that much older than homo sapiens. Garden of the Gods is young, is does not, could not posses 9990 phenomenon. She knows this, Eden knows this. Neither of them care. This is her time, he is happy to give it to her. She loves Site-898, but it's nice to get away on occasion. To be alone, if only for a little while.

She smiles as the frost brushes against her cheeks. This is her time, she's going to make the most of it.

Worn leather mountain boots tread steadily up an ancient dirt path towards the roaring fire. They are unhurried, but not unafraid. Each step carries a weight with it, a history. They have been on this trail before, they are not happy to return.

Doctor Rudy Weller marches with determination. His lungs heave in his chest, he's accustomed to the elevation, but not the air. The air here is thin, he can feel it slip through his teeth and chill his gums. It's dry, too, it's not full; there's no depth to it, no texture. It's almost hollow, as absurd of an accusation as that is.

His laces are tied, though there's only half of them, and half a pair of shoes. A large, metal protrusion demarks the space where a left leg ought to be in a naive anatomy. It's spiked to provide better grip on crags and rocks. A younger, more foolish version of him might have once mourned the 'loss', but the cave-in was thirteen years ago, that's an entire childhood, well, a childhood up to those messy years at least. Now he doesn't get foot cramps, as he often jokes.

It did hurt, though. It hurt like a motherfucker.

He can still remember that pain, but he does not live in fear of it. He will not allow himself too. And so his steps are steady as he presses up the long, worn road.

When he at last arrives at the makeshift hearth, eyes weary from many hours on mountain roads, there's already a cup of hot apple cider ready for him. He picks it up gratefully, and consumes it in lavish, starved gulps. It is just a matter of time before his host emerges from her tarp-ish cocoon to greet him, raising a gloved hand and waving with abandon. She wears these gloves even when she is in her sleeping bag. It is cold in Colorado.

WELLER: Dr. Gibbs.

GIBBS: Rudy, we're fifteen hundred miles away from protocol and the chain of command. You can call me Hellen.

WELLER: I know, I just get out of practice.

GIBBS: So, how was your drive?

WELLER: Can't complain, well, I could. But I won't. How was your flight?

GIBBS: Just fine. Pilot did a good job.

WELLER: Why'd you drag me out here?

GIBBS: I didn't drag you anywhere. I asked if you wanted to come.

WELLER: Was I suppose to say no?

GIBBS: What's your problem with this place, anyway?

WELLER: No problem. Just… it lacks gravitas. The air is boring.

GIBBS: Boring?

WELLER: Boring. And well, it's so young. Our home lies among the bones of gods, now you're asking me to come all the way here and play rocks with you. Tell me that's not a downgrade.

GIBBS: Heh. I'm glad you came.

WELLER: Yeah, me too.

DISPLAYING NOTE 2/3

1983

December 24

Doctor Hellen Gibbs is the first one awake by a good couple hours. She emerges from her tent, wandering out into the morning air and the layer of dew permeating it. Her eyes take in the nascent Rudy Weller's tent, a compact blue affair smaller even than her own. The sun is just starting to peak over the distant Rockies, casting the Earth in a purple hue. The hairs on her arms prickle with excitement and her heart pulses eight beats per minute faster. It's time for fieldwork.

The first mile of her journey is exciting. The second, exhilarating. It is seven thirteen ante-meridiem, and already rock climbers sprawl across the many spires of the garden, clambering across them with abandon and rope. Their picks chop deep yet shallow into the rock, slowly and repeatedly scarring the Earth with a thousand cuts. Of course, these cuts are small, and the Earth will forget them, as it always does.

One of the climbers, an older man, yet still below the halfway mark of his life, who really ought to have something better to do on a Saturday morning, looks down at her, noting her archeological garb. He gives her a salute, knowing she is one of the elite few who appreciates this rock as much as he does. She returns the gesture, though is slightly confused by it.

What she does not know, and what he does not know, is that this place, this rock, is going to betray them. Tonight will be a blizzard for the ages, the coldest Christmas Eve there ever was and ever would be. He does not know that in six hours, she will be wrapped up in her tent, shuddering against the cold, trying desperately to cling to life and warmth. She does not know that in six hours, he will be lying in the trunk of his Camaro, blasting the heat and burning through the gas. Neither know that in six hours, temperatures will plummet. They will fall to thirty two, and then ten, and then zero, and they will not stop. They will fall through negative fifteen, and negative thirty five, and still they will fall. Tonight, it will be seventy five degrees Fahrenheit below zero.

There is no coal in Garden of the Gods. That's not fully true, a little coal exists, but no large, useful deposits. Certainly none resembling akivite coal. 'Garden of the Gods' is a name, and just a name. But she knew that, or was pretty sure of that long before she ever came here. The investigation was warranted, but it was very much a formality.

Still, she continues walking. Dust collects on her boots and on her coat. Slightly melted snow joins it. She walks another hour, barely checking her watch, breathing at ease even through the thin air.

It is then she finds the door.

It is so almost missable, but she does not miss it. It is a slight demarcation in the sedimentary rock. She approaches with nothing more than mild curiosity, curiosity that is rewarded. It is tall, that's the first thing she notices, very tall, bordering on towering. It is at least twice as tall as her, around three point three meters if she were to guess. It is significantly thinner, however, no wider than a normal door. The rock is worn, as all the rock here is on the rare occasion that it rains in Colorado, but some of the wear is different, special. The grooves are most certainly intentional.

The grooves are shaped like tendrils of smoke, spanning the length of the door and spiraling as wisps, cut six to eight centimeters deep. A light flicks on in her brain, but it takes her time to pinpoint it. The realization happens all at once and much too fully. The grooves are the exact same shape as the patterns on her arms. And the patterns on Nerys' arms. They are a mark in a tongue never spoken by man, an ancient language of elden things. They convey a universal message: 'HERE BE DRAGONS'.

The very last thing she notices is the plaque, a metal trunk with a plastic face, engraved with a stylized picture of a bird. The words read:

Carved in 1860 by Prospector Gleann Dennis, an Irish immigrant who set out for Colorado during the Pike's Peak gold rush, Dennis spent some time camping near this area, at the base of the peak. A successful prospector, he would eventually settle down in Manitou Springs. His legacy of mining would continue until his grandson was killed in an unrelated mining accident.

It is unknown why Dennis made this carving, or what the significance of its patterns are, though this remains a topic of debate and discussion among locals.

Hellen Gibbs finishes reading the plaque and spends several minutes staring at the door. She sighs. It's time to head back to camp.

At least she won't come back empty handed.

The curvature of Rudy Weller's lips instantly betrays his stress. He looks anxiously at Gibbs as she approaches up the hill and paces in circles around the still roaring fire. He can hardly wait to speak as she approaches, but he does. Through great restraint, he allows her the first word.

GIBBS: Hey.

WELLER: Hey, how was your walk?

GIBBS: Good.

WELLER: Find any traces of 9990?

GIBBS: What do you think?

WELLER: No.

GIBBS: Go with your gut. Anyway, what's up? You seem stressed.

WELLER: There's a cold front coming in. Bad one. Real bad. First traces will arrive within the hour.

GIBBS: Sky looks peaceful.

WELLER: It won't be.

GIBBS: What do you suggest?

WELLER: Get the hell out of dodge. I'm ready to go, but I wasn't gonna leave without you.

GIBBS: Thanks Rudy, but I'll be alright. Plus, I wouldn't wanna waste my plane tickets.

WELLER: You sure?

GIBBS: Yeah. Plus I've still got some investigating to do. I found something.

WELLER: So did I.

GIBBS: You can go first.

WELLER: I've been thinking about the formations, they're a little… off, I guess. Something about them seems familiar.

GIBBS: I agree…

WELLER: I think it's a dragon, Hellen. I think they're the spines of a dragon.

GIBBS: Yeah. I've been thinking the same thing.

WELLER: That's why you want to stay.

GIBBS: Yeah.

WELLER: Alright then. I won't insist. Good luck to you. They have a pay phone at the visitor center, call me if your fingers still work in the morning.

GIBBS: Glib's not a good look on you, Rudy.

WELLER: Heh. Sorry.

DISPLAYING NOTE 3/3

1983

December 25

It is four twelve ante-meridiem and the storm has not passed. Darkness and snow shroud the Earth and her tent as a million million snowflakes are cast from the heavens and crash violently unto the dust. She is cocooned in her sleeping bag, warmed mostly by the proximity of her limbs to each other, constantly radiating heat in a cycle driven by her beating heart. But that beating is slower now.

The other, former, source of her warmth, indeed of her survival, is the fire. Before he left, she had Rudy offer up some gasoline from his tank. She whipped up a drip feed by taking a frying pan and angling it such that only a couple drops flow out at once. It worked well, the fire was kept full and burning strong and hot even against the rhythmic cold. But something has changed.

The fire's gone out.

She doesn't want to believe it, at first. Wants to believe its just the storm taking a turn for the worse, but it isn't. The storm has mostly passed, it's up to zero Fahrenheit. Yet she can feel the blood stilling in her veins.

She sighs in acknowledgement, before wriggling out of her sleeping bag. She pops on her shoes and ties them in a double knot, then reluctantly crosses the threshold to the cold. The first thing she checks is the fire, it is indeed out. It's not hard to find the culprit, the gasoline froze last night. It's only just beginning to thaw now, and without it the wood was burned through quickly. She shakes her head.

She could restart the fire, try and go to bed. But then again, it's not that cold out, she'll be fine as long as she can get her blood flowing and stay moving. Plus, this may be her best shot to mess around with the door without anyone around. She smiles, the excitement has her feeling warmer already.

Two miles in the cold is easier said than done. She can feel her heart pumping, her boots pounding relentlessly into the dirt. The human spirit to just keep going and never give up swells within her. She rubs her hands together and hugs herself for warmth. She crushes two hand-warmers in her palms and feels heat inject into her flesh. Yet these factors, all of them, melt away to reveal one singular, absolute truth:

She is fucking cold.

At first her thoughts are varied, even scattered. Thinking about the implications of the door, or of an instance, all the way out here. She thinks of tests to conduct, questions to ask. She wonders if the instance is even alive. Then her thoughts, too, converge, and soon she can only think that she is cold.

She almost misses the door, yet again. This time she does not even succeed in distinguishing it from the rock. She notices only the metal trunk of the bronze plaque, which shines harshly against the snow. She approaches, crossing sixteen meters in forty eight steps.

Were her faculties in order, she would examine the door. She would look for a handle, or a switch, or any mechanism at all. But her mind, as any mind would be, has been muted by cold. And so she knocks. First with candor, then with an unnecessary desperation. It is not that cold, she is in no danger, though her mind conceals this truth from her as well.

It is on the third knock that the door opens and her arms burn. She desperately pulls up her sleeves, gazing down at the marks. They do not glow any brighter, but they do burn. Somehow, this brings her no pain. She feels only warmth as she is recognized. Only joy as she is known.

The door slides open with a groan as an ancient mechanism is triggered revealing an interior lined with shining schist giving way to a spiraling series of stairs. She approaches with caution, but finds the endeavor wildly comforting. It is warm inside. Very warm.

The first steps she takes are slow, cautious, but they quickly increase in vigor as her blood defrost and her scientific curiosity grows. She makes many many steps deep into the Earth, but not too deep, no more than two hundred feet, this place was, after all, still carved by human hands. The steps grow rougher, more uneven as she arrives closer to the bottom. Then end on a small, barren plain, decorated only by a few rocky outcroppings.

She looks around, disappointed. There is nothing here. And then there is something. And it is an eye. A massive eye, forty six meters in diameter. It is an eye she has scarcely seen before, and always in circumstances much more desperate than this.

When it speaks to her, it is only through the pact that it gets through at all. But this is an imperfect medium, it is akin to forcing the Mississippi through a diner straw. On the first word alone she can feel her brain go numb and her nose start to bleed. A tempest rages within her mind as the enormity of the dragons thoughts come to rest upon her mind.

But this isn't her first rodeo. She grits her teeth, steels her mind, and chokes out a greeting.

GIBBS: Nice to meet you. I'm… uh, I'm Doctor Hellen Gibbs.

[A WHIMPERING FIRE. ANGRY AND ALONE. A JUDGEMENT. DISPLEASURE. TRESPASSER. DEFILIER.]

GIBBS: No! I'm just a scientist. I'm a friend of Those Below the Flames.

[DISBELIEF. VISAGE OF DEAD LEGIONS AND BURNED VILLAGES. DEATH BY MAGNETIC DYSTROPHY. NO ALLIES REMAIN.]

GIBBS: That's not true, just look at my arms.

[The notion of age. Respect and admiration. Hawaii.]

GIBBS: Yes. Her. Standing Ceaseless, Protection of Everlasting Fire. That's who I made the pact with.

[]

GIBBS: You okay? You're not saying anything.

[BEGRUGING ACCEPTANCE. Welcomeness. A fire besides a family.]

GIBBS: Thank you. I just found the door that lead here and wanted to check it out. I'm not trying to trespass.

[Acknowledgement. contemplation. CONDITION. You must stay for dinner.]

Dinner with a dragon is much like anything else with a dragon, awe inspiring, mystical, and kind of scary. They speak for a while more first, before eating, the pact struggles to translate, within fifteen minutes she gets a headache, within another fifteen, a nosebleed. This half hour is not entirely unproductive, however. She learns this instance's name is 'Slumbering Shallow, Whisper of Vacant Winds'. And, she'd been able to answer her biggest question:

How does it survive?

Typical 8007 instances live in volcanoes, and subsist off of the magma therein. Colorado has only one single active volcano, the Dotsero crater, and it's on the other end of the state. The answer, ultimately, is wind. The instance is covered in holes, she'd initially assumed they were wounds, similar to those found in deceased instances, but there's a doubt there, they are too irregular, too natural. They are, of course, not wounds, they are funnels, catching and intensifying the wind and pushing it towards a series of stone gears within. They churn in unholy gear ratios amplifying the energy until they reach the central chamber of the dragon's chest. Rather than a magmatic heart, there is a turbine. It translates this energy into the heat which keeps the instance alive and hot. While the instance's internals are very different, it's externals are very consistent with other instances. It is, still, a fire breathing dragon.

Below the turbine, there is a circuit of gears that all run into each other. This serves almost as a battery, allowing the instance to survive even when the wind is not blowing. This is rare, however. The dragon's spines form the garden of the gods and are covered in the funnels. They receive massive amounts of wind, especially on a night like tonight.

And so the dragon is very warm, and so the same for all her food.

The dragon does not eat food. It is full to bursting with an utter glut of wind.

This is good, as she does not have much food. Four Chevron-sourced slim-jims, a pack of fifty-eight honey roasted peanuts, and raspberry-honey caffeine gummies made for runners that she underestimates the strength of until she eats three two many and feels her heart accelerate to one hundred and twelve beats per minute.

The dragon offers to warm up the food for her as excess heat billows from its mouth in the form of steam and smoke. She politely declines as she does not want her food heat to eleven hundred degrees Celsius. And also because the notion of even lukewarm slim-jim makes her sick to her stomach.

Though, she does accept the entities aid in the beverage department.

Tea is fine, to her. The rest of the department likes it a lot, some to a sociopathic degree. In the break room, right next to the coffee pot, there's a matching pot of tea, keyed to the 'flavor of the day'. That changes, there's a calendar which specifies it, which Eden controls. Gibbs doesn't know it off of the top of her head. She's never actually bothered to read it. When asked what her favorite flavor of tea is, she's always replied 'Long Island'.

Her central tension with tea is not the flavor, or lack thereof, but with the process. Waiting several minutes for the water to boil, made all the longer given how weak the power is; the outlets in the break room are fifty volts max; for a end product that is only slightly better than water. She's willing to go through the process for coffee, mostly because she's probably chemically addicted to it, but it's just not worth it for tea.

This is a complaint that evaporates instantly in the presence of a dragon which can boil water in five sixteenths of a second. And, as a responsible hiker, she does carry both tea and water. Within half a minute there's a complete, steaming cup of peppermint tea.

Still, she'd prefer it were Long Island.

The dragon does not speak as she eats, it leaves her mind, and the pact, in peace. It is only when she is done and fed and full; relatively at least; that it again imposes its mind.

[The gnashing of teeth. The burning of acid. The feeling of satisfaction.]

GIBBS: Was it good? Yeah. Well, it was basically a gas station dinner, but it was good.

[Contentment.]

GIBBS: Can I ask you a question? Scientific curiosity. What's your relation to the others? Are you a subspecies?

[No. REEVALUATION. Maybe.]

GIBBS: How did you get like this?

[A burning fire. Normalcy. Complacence. Exhaustion. Reinvention.]

[Departure. Coldness. COLDNESS. Desperation. LONGING. Adaptation.]

[Wind and water on rock. Erosion. THE SPLITTING OF SKIN. AGONY. THE CHURNING OF GEARS. REINVENTION.]

[Rebirth. Travel. Settling. Normalcy. Complacence.]

The last few thoughts, few sentences, carry massive waves of emotion. The pact burns her body with agony as her mind flares and bends under the pressure. Her heart beats at one hundred forty six beats per minute for eighteen seconds before the agony subsides. But the message is clear. The instance altered its body by force; possibly magic, possibly natural; at no small cost and not without one.

Of course, this only serves to create more questions in her querying heart and burning arms.

GIBBS: But why? Why undergo that process?

[Scarred human shoulders shrugging. Indifference. Unknown.]

GIBBS: You don't know?

[A river's course splitting around a rock. A fork in the road.]

GIBBS: You wanted to change?

[]

GIBBS: Were you trying to get away from everyone else?

[]

GIBBS: Why?

[Site-898. A plane. HER. Arriving here.]

GIBBS: No! No. I'm not running away from anyone. I spend most vacations at 898. I just thought it was time I used a vacation to actually, you know, go somewhere.

[POWERFUL WINDS. SWIRLING STORMS. THE PEAK OF THE GARDEN OF THE GODS. THE ZENITH OF HE ABOVE THE WINDS. A SENSE OF ACCOMPLISHMENT.]

GIBBS: The top of you? What about it?

[The notion of understanding.]

GIBBS: You want me to climb up there? To understand?

[YES.]

Doctor Hellen Gibbs is on a mountain. Her fingers tense in pain as she white knuckles each crag and approaches the three hundred foot summit. She's in no real danger, the dragon is helping her, blowing warm wind on her hands and face so that they do not chill or freeze. Additionally, she is secured by a rope and years of experience. Still, this is a rather extreme physical feat for her, or, well, anybody.

The first hundred feet are tiring. The second hundred are miserable. The last hundred are herculean. They are altogether easier than her doctoral thesis.

The winds blow ferociously at her as the forces of Gǎ-oh and Njörðr combine to push her away from the rock, where the forces of gravity will return her swiftly to the Earth. But she does not fall. And her knuckles strain. And her arms strain.

The energy given unto her by the slim-jims is quickly expended, followed by lunch and breakfast and six more meals before that. After the first five minutes she is sweating water she never even drank.

She only ever actually slips once. A patch of ice in a hold that she cannot see when she grasps it. Her palm slips out of it and is scraped up by the sharp rock, her other hand fails to fully compensate and slips out too, and she falls. She clambers desperately for the rope, grasping on with vigor and swinging towards the rock. She kicks her feet towards the wall repeatedly to slow her descent until she can reestablish the hold. She loses at most twenty five feet overall, though her confidence is, slightly, shaken.

And so it is that she is thoroughly exhausted by the time she reaches the peak.

She hefts her shaking, freezing form up onto the ridge, her torso splayed across the edge. Every one of her pores dilates in frigidity and her teeth chatter in defiance of the stillness. She is not done.

Slowly, but certainly, limb by limb, she rights herself, so that her feet balance precariously on the peak. She is truly cold, now. The dragon's air cannot warm her, it does not want to risk blowing her off.

She gazes up at the wintry moon, it's color is the same as the snow. But then, she's never been one for gazing at the sky.

She then looks out, over the landscape. Out into the expanse, away from the Rockies. There is low visibility, she cannot see far, likely no farther than twenty miles, but that is not what matters. She understands, now, why Slumbering Shallow came out here. It is breathtaking, it is unlike anywhere she has ever been. It is unique and singular and singularly unique and more than any of these things it is isolated and alone and lonely. If she wanted, as it had suggested, to run away, there would be no finer a place.

But that is not what she wants. Not at all. What matters about this view, about these twenty miles, is that past the storm, past another twenty miles and another and a hundred and a thousand and a couple hundred more, there is Site-898, and they are staring right back at her, probably through dorky yellow binoculars.

She smiles, she feels the cold winds brush against her rosy cheeks and chill her frigid skin as she stands three hundred feet above the sallow Earth.

And for a moment she is on top of the world.
